elements.text: 28:16-31 By the sacrifices enjoined in this chapter, we are reminded of the continued power of the sacrifice of Christ, and of our continual need to depend thereon. No hurrying employments, or perilous situations, or prosperous circumstances, should cause slackness in our religious exercises; but should rather stir us up to greater diligence in seeking help from, or giving thanks to the Lord. And all is to be accompanied with repentance, faith is the Lord Jesus, and love to him, and to produce true holiness in our conduct towards all men; otherwise God will abhor our most solemn services and abundant devotions. And Christ is able to supply the wants of every day, every week, every month, every year, every ordinance, every case.

The Passover offering was the same as that of the New moon, and was repeated on each of the seven days of the festival, thus marking the importance and the solemnity of the occasion. The details of the offering had not been previously prescribed.

16-25. in the fourteenth day of the first month is the passoverâ€”The law for that great annual festival is given (Le 23:5), but some details are here introduced, as certain specified offerings are prescribed to be made on each of the seven days of unleavened bread [Nu 28:18-25].
No text from Poole on this verse.

name: Gill's Exposition of the Entire Bible

elements.text: And on the seventh day ye shall have an holy convocation,.... As on the first:
ye shall do no servile work; unless in dressing food.

children.text: ye shall do no servile work; unless in dressing food.

elements.text: And on the seventh day ye shall have an holy convocation; ye shall do no servile work.

name: Keil and Delitzsch Biblical Commentary on the Old Testament

elements.text: The festal sacrifices of the seven days were to be prepared "in addition to the morning burnt-offering, which served as the continual burnt-offering." This implies that the festal sacrifices commanded were to be prepared and offered every day after the morning sacrifice.
